title: Biological Activities and Safety of Citrus spp. Essential Oils
author: Noura S Dosoky; William N Setzer; Dosoky; Noura S; Setzer; William N
description: Citrus fruits have been a commercially important crop for thousands of years. In addition, Citrus essential oils are valuable in the perfume, food, and beverage industries, and have also enjoyed use as aromatherapy and medicinal agents. This review summarizes the important biological activities and safety considerations of the essential oils of sweet orange (Citrus sinensis), bitter orange (Citrus aurantium), neroli (Citrus aurantium), orange petitgrain (Citrus aurantium), mandarin (Citrus reticulata), lemon (Citrus limon), lime (Citrus aurantifolia), grapefruit (Citrus × paradisi), bergamot (Citrus bergamia), Yuzu (Citrus junos), and kumquat (Citrus japonica).
cleaned_text: Biological Activities and Safety of Citrus spp. Essential Oils [https://doi.org/10.3390/ijms19071966](https://doi.org/10.3390/ijms19071966) [Plant origin of Citrus is still controversial; however, it is believed to have originated from Southeast Asia [ [2](#B2-ijms-19-01966)]. Citrus is grown widely all over the world for its numerous health benefits. Citrus fruits are consumed as a fresh fruit desert or used for making juice and jam. They are an excellent source of vitamins, especially vitamin C. Processing Citrus fruits results in a significant amount of waste (peels, seeds, and pulps), which accounts for 50% of the fruit [ [3](#B3-ijms-19-01966)]. Citrus waste is a valuable source of d-limonene, flavonoids, carotenoids, dietary fibers, soluble sugars, cellulose, hemicellulose, pectin, polyphenols, ascorbic acid, methane, and essential oils [ [4](#B4-ijms-19-01966), [5](#B5-ijms-19-01966), [6](#B6-ijms-19-01966)]. Interestingly, the essential oil (EO) is the most vital by-product of Citrus processing. Citrus EOs are broadly used as natural food additives in several food and beverage products [ [7](#B7-ijms-19-01966)] because they have been classified as generally recognized as safe (GRAS) [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. Furthermore, Citrus EOs are used as natural preservatives due to their broad spectrum of biological activities including antimicrobial and antioxidant effects [ [9](#B9-ijms-19-01966)]. The presence of terpenes, flavonoids, carotenes, and coumarins is thought to be responsible for the strong anti-oxidative and antimicrobial activities [ [10](#B10-ijms-19-01966), [11](#B11-ijms-19-01966), [12](#B12-ijms-19-01966), [13](#B13-ijms-19-01966), [14](#B14-ijms-19-01966)]. Due to their pleasant refreshing smell and rich aroma, Citrus EOs are also used in air-fresheners, household cleaning products, perfumes, cosmetics, and medicines. [15](#B15-ijms-19-01966), [16](#B16-ijms-19-01966), [17](#B17-ijms-19-01966), [18](#B18-ijms-19-01966), [19](#B19-ijms-19-01966)]. The key volatile components are presented in [Figure 1](#ijms-19-01966-f001). Sweet orange, bitter orange, mandarin, and grapefruit EOs are rich in monoterpenes with the major component being d-limonene (65.3-95.9%) ( [Table 1](#ijms-19-01966-t001)) [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. The main components in the essential oil of bitter orange leaf are linalyl acetate and linalool [ [16](#B16-ijms-19-01966)], while the flower EO contained linalool as the major component, followed by d-limonene and linalyl acetate [ [20](#B20-ijms-19-01966)]. Some of the Citrus EOs are prepared by expression, which results in the presence of non-volatile components ( [Figure 2](#ijms-19-01966-f002)) that can cause photosensitivity and skin irritation [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. The percentages of these non-volatile constituents in expressed oils are given in [Table 2](#ijms-19-01966-t002). 2. Biological Properties [Table 3](#ijms-19-01966-t003). 2.1. Sweet Orange (Citrus sinensis L.) Essential Oil [28](#B28-ijms-19-01966)] and human colon cancer cells [ [29](#B29-ijms-19-01966)], and inhibiting angiogenesis and metastasis [ [29](#B29-ijms-19-01966)]. Olfactory stimulation using orange EO induced physiological and psychological relaxation. Inhalation of orange EO for 90 s caused a significant decrease in oxyhemoglobin concentration in the right prefrontal cortex of the brain which increases comfortable, relaxed, and natural feelings [ [30](#B30-ijms-19-01966)]. The odor of sweet orange decreases the symptoms of anxiety and improves the mood [ [31](#B31-ijms-19-01966)]. The oil showed strong anxiolytic activity in Wistar rats [ [32](#B32-ijms-19-01966)]. When female dental patients were exposed to sweet orange odor diffused in the waiting room prior to a dental procedure, they showed lower levels of state-anxiety compared to control patients who were exposed to air only [ [33](#B33-ijms-19-01966)]. Sweet orange EO in combination with ginger and accompanied by a massage was effective in alleviating moderate to severe knee pain among the elderly in Hong Kong [ [34](#B34-ijms-19-01966)]. Moreover, sweet orange EO suppressed pre-neoplastic hepatic lesions during N-nitrosodiethylamine (DEN)-induced hepatocarcinogenesis by the normal phenotype and upregulating junctional complexes [ [35](#B35-ijms-19-01966)]. Injections of orange EO in mice 24 h after subcutaneous injections with dibenzo-[]-pyrene (DBP) reduced the tumor incidence to less than 50% after 30 weeks [ [36](#B36-ijms-19-01966)]. In addition, the oil was reported to have a good radical-scavenging activity [ [37](#B37-ijms-19-01966)], mainly due to the high d-limonene content [ [12](#B12-ijms-19-01966), [13](#B13-ijms-19-01966)]. It is used in combination with thyme oil to improve the quality traits of marinated chicken meat [ [38](#B38-ijms-19-01966)]. Moreover, formulations based on orange and sweet basil oils were effective in treating acne [ [39](#B39-ijms-19-01966)]. Improvement of the acne condition was observed with 43-75% clearance of lesions. It should be noted that there were some side effects, such as burning and redness that disappeared within a few minutes of completing the application [ [39](#B39-ijms-19-01966)]. Sweet orange EO was reported to inhibit the growth of several bacteria including Staphylococcus aureus, Listeria monocytogenes, Vibrio species, It also showed a good anti-aflatoxigenic effects (inhibited aflatoxin B1) at 500 ppm [ [44](#B44-ijms-19-01966)]. In addition, it has an intense larvicidal activity against the malaria vector, Anopheles labranchiae [ [46](#B46-ijms-19-01966)], and the vector of yellow and dengue fever, Aedes aegypti [ [47](#B47-ijms-19-01966)]. Sweet orange EO is a potent fumigant against house flies, cockroaches, and mosquitoes [ [48](#B48-ijms-19-01966), [49](#B49-ijms-19-01966)]. It can be used for controlling subterranean termites [ [50](#B50-ijms-19-01966)]. It is also an effective anthelmintic agent against gastrointestinal nematodes; five times more effective on Haemonchus contortus eggs than tea tree EO [ [51](#B51-ijms-19-01966)]. Moreover, sweet orange EO acted as a growth promoter, increased immunity, and improved disease resistance to Streptococcus iniae in Tilapia [ [52](#B52-ijms-19-01966)]. 2.2. Bitter Orange (Citrus aurantium L.) Essential Oil [53](#B53-ijms-19-01966)]. It also enhances sleeping time and is used to treat insomnia [ [54](#B54-ijms-19-01966)]. Bitter orange odor decreases the symptoms of anxiety, improves mood, and creates a sense of well-being [ [53](#B53-ijms-19-01966)]. It showed strong anxiolytic activity in rodents without any motor impairment, even after 15 consecutive days of treatment [ [55](#B55-ijms-19-01966)]. It increased social interactions for rats (time spent in active social interaction), and increased exploration time in the open arms of the elevated plus-maze (EPM) [ [55](#B55-ijms-19-01966)]. It was also effective in treating the symptoms of anxiety in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia prior to the collection of medullary material [ [56](#B56-ijms-19-01966)]. It exerted its antianxiety effects by regulating serotonin (5-HT) receptors in rats [ [57](#B57-ijms-19-01966)] and its antidepressant effects through the monoaminergic system in mice [ [58](#B58-ijms-19-01966)]. Furthermore, bitter orange EO was effective in reducing the severity of first-stage labor pain and anxiety in primiparous women [ [59](#B59-ijms-19-01966)], as well as in alleviating moderate and severe knee pain [ [34](#B34-ijms-19-01966)]. Bitter orange EO is used as a natural antiseizure and anticonvulsant agent. It has been used in treating epilepsy and seizures [ [54](#B54-ijms-19-01966)]. It has been reported to have anti-spasmodic effect and to enhance sexual desire [ [59](#B59-ijms-19-01966)]. Due to the presence of limonene, bitter orange EO possesses its gastroprotective and ulcer healing actions through increasing the gastric production of mucus, which is useful as a secondary intervention in the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases [ [60](#B60-ijms-19-01966)]. It is used as a treatment for digestive disorders such as slow digestion, constipation, flatulence, gastric problems, etc. [ [53](#B53-ijms-19-01966)]. Bitter orange EO suppressed preneoplastic hepatic lesions during DEN-induced hepatocarcinogenesis in rats by restoring the normal phenotype and upregulating junctional complexes [ [35](#B35-ijms-19-01966)]. Bitter orange EO showed good radical-scavenging activity [ [53](#B53-ijms-19-01966)], largely due to the high d-limonene content [ [12](#B12-ijms-19-01966), [13](#B13-ijms-19-01966)] and its microencapsulated form, which was effective in reducing oxidative stress in acute otitis media rats [ [61](#B61-ijms-19-01966)]. Due to its free radical-scavenging properties, bitter orange extract showed nephroprotective effects against gentamicin-induced renal damage [ [62](#B62-ijms-19-01966)]. The antibacterial activity of bitter orange EO was manifested by inhibiting the growth of Listeria effective controlling multi-species biofilms [ [65](#B65-ijms-19-01966)]. Due to its antimicrobial effects, bitter orange EO is used for treating colds, dull skin, flu, gums and mouth, and chronic bronchitis, as well as a food preservative [ [53](#B53-ijms-19-01966)]. The diluted oil is used to treat pimples and acne [ [53](#B53-ijms-19-01966)]. In addition, bitter orange EO inhibits the growth of Penicillium digitatum, and P. italicum [ [15](#B15-ijms-19-01966), [53](#B53-ijms-19-01966)]. The oil was mentioned as a topical treatment for skin fungal infections like ringworm, jock itch, and athlete's foot [ [66](#B66-ijms-19-01966)]. Furthermore, bitter orange EO showed potent and against the silverleaf whitefly, Bemisia tabaci [ [67](#B67-ijms-19-01966)]. It was also effective against the larvae of the malaria vector, Anopheles labranchiae [ [46](#B46-ijms-19-01966)]. (Citrus aurantium L.) [55](#B55-ijms-19-01966)]. Neroli EO is effective for cardiac palpitations resulting from shock or fear [ [68](#B68-ijms-19-01966)]. Similar to the fruit peel oil, the odor of neroli decreases the symptoms of anxiety, improves mood, and creates a sense of well-being [ [53](#B53-ijms-19-01966)]. It was proven to be effective in reducing preoperative anxiety before minor operations [ [69](#B69-ijms-19-01966)]. Neroli EO reduced the mean anxiety scores in postmenopausal women [ [70](#B70-ijms-19-01966)]. It exerted its antianxiety effects by regulating 5-HT receptors in rats [ [57](#B57-ijms-19-01966)]. Neroli EO is used as a natural antiseizure and anticonvulsant agent [ [71](#B71-ijms-19-01966)]. It has been used in treating insomnia, epilepsy, and seizures [ [72](#B72-ijms-19-01966)]. Neroli EO has central and peripheral antinociceptive effects which support the ethnomedicinal claims of its use in the management of pain and inflammation [ [73](#B73-ijms-19-01966)]. Neroli EO possesses significant anti-inflammatory activity against acute and chronic inflammation [ [73](#B73-ijms-19-01966)]. Neroli EO is effective in reducing stress and improving the endocrine system. Inhalation of neroli EO helps in relieving menopausal symptoms, reducing blood pressure, and increasing sexual desire in postmenopausal women [ [74](#B74-ijms-19-01966)]. It also decreased the overall symptoms of premenstrual syndrome (PMS) in university students. It showed positive effects on the mood, blood pressure, pain, inflammation, bloating, and indigestion in addition to its anti-depressant effects [ [75](#B75-ijms-19-01966)]. Inhaling neroli odor enhances sexual desire [59](#B59-ijms-19-01966)]. Neroli EO is an endothelium- and smooth-muscle-dependent vasodilator that can alleviate cardiovascular symptoms. The endothelial component is mediated by the nitric oxide to soluble guanylyl cyclase pathway, while the smooth muscle component involves inhibiting extracellular Ca2+ influx and store-operated Ca2+ release mediated by the ryanodine receptor (RyR) signaling pathway [ [76](#B76-ijms-19-01966)]. Inhaling a mixture of lavender, ylang-ylang, marjoram, and neroli (20:15:10:2) decreased systolic and diastolic blood pressure, as well as the concentration of salivary cortisol in prehypertensive and hypertensive subjects [ [77](#B77-ijms-19-01966)]. These positive effects were immediate and continuous [ [77](#B77-ijms-19-01966)]. Furthermore, neroli EO is a strong antioxidant. It showed a 100% singlet oxygen scavenging activity at all concentrations between 0.1 and 2% [ [20](#B20-ijms-19-01966), [78](#B78-ijms-19-01966)]. Interestingly, the C. aurantium flower extract showed anti-amnesic and repairing effects on memory, learning impairments, and behavioral disorders induced by scopolamine, and has the potential to treat Alzheimer's disease [ [72](#B72-ijms-19-01966)]. Neroli EO inhibits the growth of several bacteria including Bacillus subtilis, B. cereus, Staphylococcus aureus, [53](#B53-ijms-19-01966), [79](#B79-ijms-19-01966)], as well as several fungi including Aspergillus niger, flavus, A. nidulans, Oil [78](#B78-ijms-19-01966), [80](#B80-ijms-19-01966)]. The potent antioxidant effect could be attributed to the high d-limonene content [ [12](#B12-ijms-19-01966), [13](#B13-ijms-19-01966)]. It also inhibited the growth of Bacillus subtilis, Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Mucor Essential [82](#B82-ijms-19-01966)]. C. reticulata EO showed a moderate radical scavenging activity [ [83](#B83-ijms-19-01966)] mainly due to the high d-limonene content [ [12](#B12-ijms-19-01966)]. Mandarin oil is well known for its broad spectrum antibacterial and antifungal actions. It inhibits the growth of several bacteria including Escherichia coli, Bacillus subtilis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Staphylococcus aureus [ [83](#B83-ijms-19-01966), [84](#B84-ijms-19-01966)], as well as several fungi including Penicillium [89](#B89-ijms-19-01966)]. Lemon EO showed cytotoxic effects against human prostate, lung, and breast cancer cells [ [90](#B90-ijms-19-01966)]. It also induced apoptosis in HL-60 cells due to the presence of citral, decanal, and octanal [ [28](#B28-ijms-19-01966)]. Oral administration of lemon inhibited 4-(methylnitrosamino)-1-(3-pyridyl)-1-butanone (NNK)-induced neoplasia of the lungs and forestomach of female mice [ [91](#B91-ijms-19-01966)]. Lemon EO causes activation of the sympathetic nerve activity innervating the white adipose tissue (WAT), which increases lipolysis and results in the suppression of body weight gain [ [92](#B92-ijms-19-01966)]. Lemon EO significantly reduces lipid peroxidation levels and nitrile content, but increases reduced glutathione (GSH) levels, as well as superoxide dismutase, catalase, and peroxidase activities in mouse hippocampus [ [93](#B93-ijms-19-01966)]. The neuroprotective effect of lemon EO is attributed to its remarkable radical-scavenging activity [ [94](#B94-ijms-19-01966), [95](#B95-ijms-19-01966)]. Prolonged exposure (for 2 weeks) to lemon EO induces significant changes in neuronal circuits involved in anxiety and pain in rats [ [96](#B96-ijms-19-01966)]. Lemon EO improves creativity and mood, and is thought to affect heart rhythm [ [97](#B97-ijms-19-01966)]. The analgesic effect of lemon EO is induced by dopamine-related activation of anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and the descending pain inhibitory system [ [98](#B98-ijms-19-01966)]. Inhalation of lemon EO reduces the intensity of nausea and vomiting of pregnancy (NVP) by 33% [ [99](#B99-ijms-19-01966)]. It also showed anti-spasmodic activity [ [89](#B89-ijms-19-01966)]. Lemon EO significantly enhanced attention level, concentration, cognitive performance, mood, and memory of students during the learning process [ [100](#B100-ijms-19-01966)]. Rats exposed to lemon EO were able to find a target point faster than a control group [ [89](#B89-ijms-19-01966)]. Lemon EO is a safe and effective penetration enhancer for topical administration of lipid- and water-soluble vitamins which are critical issues for the protection of anti-ageing formulations. It significantly enhances the trans-epidermal release of -tocopherol (vitamin E), retinyl acetate (vitamin A), pyridoxine (vitamin B6), and ascorbic acid (vitamin C) from topical emulsions in reconstructed human epidermis [ [101](#B101-ijms-19-01966)]. In addition, lemon EO is [ [102](#B102-ijms-19-01966), [103](#B103-ijms-19-01966)], and effects against the malaria vector, Anopheles stephensi [ [104](#B104-ijms-19-01966)]. It also showed remarkable miticidal activity against Sarcoptes scabiei var. cuniculi, both in vitro and in vivo. When lemon EO was tested at 20% and applied topically on the infected parts of rabbits once a week for four successive weeks, the infected rabbits completely recovered after the second week of treatment [ [105](#B105-ijms-19-01966)]. 2.7. Bergamot (Citrus bergamia Risso & Poit) Essential Oil [125](#B125-ijms-19-01966)]. It is used in suntan preparations due to the presence of bergapten, which is the active melanogenic component [ [126](#B126-ijms-19-01966)]. Bergamot EO is used in complementary medicine to treat chronic nociceptive and neuropathic pain via modulating sensitive perception of pain [ [127](#B127-ijms-19-01966), [128](#B128-ijms-19-01966), [129](#B129-ijms-19-01966)]. Intraplantar injection of bergamot EO, linalool, and acetate showed a peripheral antinociception effect in the capsaicin test mediated by a peripheral opioid mechanism [ [129](#B129-ijms-19-01966), [130](#B130-ijms-19-01966)]. A combination of a low dose of morphine with inactive doses of bergamot oil or linalool was sufficient to induce antiallodynic effects in mice via inhibiting spinal extracellular signal-regulated protein kinase (ERK) phosphorylation [ [127](#B127-ijms-19-01966), [131](#B131-ijms-19-01966)]. The oil is used to facilitate wound healing [ [132](#B132-ijms-19-01966)]. Bergamot EO was reported to be cytotoxic against SH-SY5Y human neuroblastoma cells, suppressing their growth rate through a mechanism related to both apoptotic and necrotic cell death [ [133](#B133-ijms-19-01966), [134](#B134-ijms-19-01966)]. Bergamottin and 5-geranyloxy-7-methoxycoumarin were identified as the bioactive molecules responsible for the cytotoxic effect of bergamot EO [ [133](#B133-ijms-19-01966)]. Bergamot EO inhibited tumor formation by the carcinogen NDMA in vitro by more than 70% [ [136](#B136-ijms-19-01966)]. Bergamot oil and its d-Limonene were reported to modulate autophagic pathways in SH-SY5Y cells [ [125](#B125-ijms-19-01966)]. Liposomal bergamot oil showed improved anticancer activity against SH-SY5Y cells because of its higher stability and higher bioavailability [ [135](#B135-ijms-19-01966)]. In addition, it has been shown to reduce neuronal damage caused in vitro by excitotoxic stimuli by preventing an injury-induced decrease of EO is used as a mild sedative that acts by calming and soothing the nervous system [ [139](#B139-ijms-19-01966)]. In rodent experiments, the pleasant, refreshing odor of bergamot decreased the symptoms of stress-induced anxiety and minimized behavior-related depressive disorders in chronic stressed rats [ [139](#B139-ijms-19-01966)]. Inhalation of bergamot EO was reported to increase the release of amino acid neurotransmitters (glutamate, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), hippocampuses, both in vivo and in vitro, which suggested that the oil may interfere with exocytosis [ [165](#B165-ijms-19-01966)]. Similar to diazepam, bergamot oil exerted anxiolytic-like behaviors and attenuated hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis activity via reducing the corticosterone response to acute stress caused by EPM [ [140](#B140-ijms-19-01966)]. A pilot study performed in the waiting room of a mental health treatment center (Utah, USA) revealed that inhalation of bergamot EO for 15 minutes improves positive feelings [ [141](#B141-ijms-19-01966)]. Furthermore, bergamot EO showed a good radical scavenging activity evaluated by -carotene bleaching test (IC50 = 42.6 µg/mL) [ [109](#B109-ijms-19-01966)] due the high d-limonene content [ [12](#B12-ijms-19-01966), [13](#B13-ijms-19-01966)]. Safety of Citrus Oils [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. They are not hazardous in pregnancy and do not alter the maternal reproductive outcome [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966), [166](#B166-ijms-19-01966)]. Sweet orange, bitter orange, neroli, petitgrain, lemon, lime (both distilled and expressed), bergamot, and grapefruit oils have GRAS status [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. However, there is a possible skin sensitization issue if old or oxidized oil is used. The distilled oils are not phototoxic, while the expressed oils carry a low to moderate risk of phototoxicity ( [Table 4](#ijms-19-01966-t004)) [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)] due to the presence of furanocoumarins [ [168](#B168-ijms-19-01966)]. In case of applying expressed EOs to the skin in a dose higher than the maximum dermal use level, it is recommended to avoid exposure to sunlight for at least 12 h [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. Neroli and yuzu oils are neither irritating nor sensitizing [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)]. Expressed sweet orange oil was neither irritating nor sensitizing to 25 volunteers when tested at 8 and 100% [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)], whereas it caused sensitivity to 0.13% of total dermatitis patients when tested at 2% [ [169](#B169-ijms-19-01966)]. Bitter orange EO was neither irritating nor sensitizing to 25 volunteers when tested at 10% [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)], while it caused sensitivity to 1.5% of total dermatitis patients when tested at 2% [ [169](#B169-ijms-19-01966)]. Lemon oil was neither irritating nor sensitizing to volunteers when tested at 10% [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)], and similar results were observed for distilled lime oil when tested at 15 and 100% [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)]. No irritation or sensitization data were found for the expressed lime oil. The high citral content of lime EO causes potential toxic and myelotoxic effects [ [110](#B110-ijms-19-01966)]. Grapefruit oil was neither irritating nor sensitizing to volunteers when tested at 10 and 100% [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)]. Mandarin EO was neither irritating nor sensitizing to 25 volunteers when tested at 5 and 8% [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)]. The expressed bergamot oil was neither irritating nor sensitizing to 25 volunteers when tested at 10% [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)]. It caused no irritation when tested at 2% on 1200 dermatitis patients, with only two (0.17%) patients showing sensitivity reaction [ [170](#B170-ijms-19-01966)], whereas when tested at 10% in 590 eczema patients, 0.5% of the patients had reactions [ [171](#B171-ijms-19-01966)]. Expressed bergamot oil caused severe phototoxic effects in hairless mice and pigs using simulated sunlight, and in humans using natural sunlight and may be photocarcinogenic [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)]. When applied to mice, then irradiated with UV light, bergamot oil showed a carcinogenic action due to the presence of bergapten [ [172](#B172-ijms-19-01966)]. Chronic skin pigmentation (also known as berloque dermatitis, bergapten dermatitis, or photophytodermatitis) can also develop. Increased exposure to UV light can lead to serious burns [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. In the absence of UV light, bergamot oil is not carcinogenic and even low concentration sunscreens can completely inhibit bergapten-enhanced phototumorigenesis [ [172](#B172-ijms-19-01966)]. No hazards found for the furanocoumarin-free (FCF) or rectified bergamot oil. The rectified oil was not sensitizing when tested at 30% on 25 volunteers [ [173](#B173-ijms-19-01966)]. [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. The use of old or oxidized oils should be avoided. To avoid any possible adverse skin reactions, it is recommended to dilute Citrus oils with a carrier oil before topical use [ [174](#B174-ijms-19-01966)]. Also, adding an antioxidant to preparations containing Citrus oils is recommended [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. 4. Bioactivity and Safety of Individual Key Components 4.1. d-Limonene [12](#B12-ijms-19-01966)], and anticarcinogenic [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)] effects. It is not acutely toxic, nephrotoxic, or carcinogenic, but the oxidized d-limonene may carry some toxicity. Unoxidized d-limonene is listed as an allergen by the EU, and moderately allergenic in Germany [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. Unoxidized d-limonene was allergenic in 0.2% of dermatitis patients when tested at 2-3% [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. No positive skin reactions were observed when testing the 98% pure d-limonene at 20% in dermatitis patients [ [175](#B175-ijms-19-01966)]. Undiluted d-limonene was moderately irritating to rabbits [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)]. d-Limonene was irritating at concentrations of 70-80%, a weak irritant at 50%, and a non-irritant at concentrations of 20-30%. The acute dermal LD50 of d-limonene was >5 g/kg rabbits, while the acute oral LD50 was >5 g/kg in rats [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)]. 4.2. -Terpinene [176](#B176-ijms-19-01966)]. It is neither irritating nor sensitizing [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)]. It possesses minimal toxicity. Depending on concentration, it may be mutagenic or non-mutagenic [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. The acute dermal LD50 of -terpinene was >5 g/kg rabbits, while the acute oral LD50 was [178](#B178-ijms-19-01966), [179](#B179-ijms-19-01966), [180](#B180-ijms-19-01966)]. It is neither toxic nor irritable to skin. It presents an extremely low risk of skin sensitization [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. No positive skin reactions were observed when testing the 97% pure linalool at 20%, or to oxidized linalool tested dermatitis and eczema patients [181](#B181-ijms-19-01966)]. Linalool does not cause photo-irritation or photo-allergy because it does not absorb UV light in the range of 290-400 nm [ [182](#B182-ijms-19-01966)]. No fetal toxicity was observed [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. No carcinogenic, mutagenic, or genotoxic activities were found [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. The acute dermal LD50 was 5.61 g/kg in rabbits, while the acute oral LD50 was 2.79 g/kg in rats [ [183](#B183-ijms-19-01966)] and 2.2-3.92 g/kg in mice [ [184](#B184-ijms-19-01966)]. High doses linalool ataxia and narcosis [ [185](#B185-ijms-19-01966)]. 4.4. Linalyl Acetate [177](#B177-ijms-19-01966)]. It is non-toxic, and is very minimally skin reactive [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. When tested at 5-20%, no skin reaction was observed [ [186](#B186-ijms-19-01966)]. Similar to linalool, linalyl acetate does not cause photo-irritation or photo-allergy because it does not absorb UV light in the range of 290-400 nm [ [182](#B182-ijms-19-01966)]. It has no carcinogenic activity [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. The acute dermal LD50 was higher than 5 g/kg in rabbits, while the acute oral LD50 was 14.5 g/kg in rats and 13.5 g/kg in mice [ [184](#B184-ijms-19-01966)]. 4.5. -Terpineol 4.6. Geranyl antifungal [ [189](#B189-ijms-19-01966)], and antimicrobial properties [ [190](#B190-ijms-19-01966)]. It is a very weak skin sensitizer [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)]. It is neither toxic nor carcinogenic [ [8](#B8-ijms-19-01966)]. It was not mutagenic in the Ames test [ [191](#B191-ijms-19-01966)], and had no genotoxic effect [ [192](#B192-ijms-19-01966)]. The acute oral LD50 of geranyl acetate is 6.33 It is not or [ It is generally a non-irritant and non-sensitizing. The acute dermal rabbits, subcutaneous LD50 was 1.42 g/kg in mice, and the acute oral LD50 was >5 g/kg in rats [ [167](#B167-ijms-19-01966)]. 5.
